choices.text: Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries
Sphenopalatine artery
Greater palatine artery
Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Arterial supply of the nose:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System -

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: Incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery), contributes to the arterial supply of Kiesselbach's plexus. It gives rise to the nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Incorrect because the septal branch of the greater palatine artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum and participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: Incorrect as this artery, a branch of the facial artery (which stems from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to the Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Kiesselbach's plexus -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The Jacobson nerve / tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Jacobson nerve = tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (IX cranial nerve) – supplies middle ear mucosa. Referred otalgia from tonsillitis / pharyngitis / Cancers of base of tongue is due to this nerve common innervation (ear & pharynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater Auricular Nerve: Arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and primarily innervates the skin over the parotid gland and mastoid region, not typically involved in referred ear pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which innervates the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus, contributing to sensations in these areas but not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve: Also known as Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and part of the external auditory canal and could potentially contribute to referred otalgia, but not primarily responsible in cases of tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.text: What are Kraissl’s lines?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relaxed tension lines in skin

 

Kraissl’s lines, also known as relaxed skin tension lines (RSTLs), are lines on the skin that indicate the natural orientation of the skin under minimal or no tension. They are used in surgical planning, particularly in cosmetic surgery, to guide incisions so that they heal with the least visible scars. Kraissl’s lines differ from Langer's lines, which also describe lines of skin tension but are based on the alignment of collagen fibers within the dermis and are typically used to predict surgical wound healing outcomes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point of maximum tension in a fracture: Refers to the area where the mechanical stress is greatest on a broken bone, unrelated to skin tension lines.

 

Option C. Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury: Would refer to the orientation of these fibers in response to a penetrating trauma, which is not what Kraissl’s lines describe.

 

Option D. Point of tension in hanging: Refers to the mechanical stress points exerted during a hanging, specifically on the neck, which has no relation to the relaxed skin tension lines described by Kraissl.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Kraissl’s lines are crucial for surgical incision planning to ensure scars are minimally visible following healing, highlighting the importance of understanding skin tension dynamics in medical procedures.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

choices.text: Ear pain and fever
Tympanic membrane bulging

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability for the past two days. The child has been complaining of ear discomfort, especially at night. There is no history of recent trauma or head injury. On physical examination, his temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), and the physician explains the typical findings associated with his condition and evaluates for any signs that may indicate an alternative diagnosis. Which of the following features is typically absent in a case of otitis media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Battle's sign

 

Explanation:


Battle’s sign, characterized by bruising over the mastoid process, is indicative of a basilar skull fracture, particularly involving the temporal bone. It is not seen in otitis media, which is an infection of the middle ear. Battle’s sign is associated with cranial trauma and should prompt evaluation for skull fractures rather than middle ear infections. The presence of this sign suggests a traumatic origin rather than an inflammatory or infectious process like otitis media.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Ear pain and fever: These are common findings in otitis media due to the inflammation and infection of the middle ear space, often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever.

 

Option B. Tympanic membrane bulging: A bulging tympanic membrane is a hallmark of otitis media, caused by fluid accumulation and increased pressure in the middle ear.

 

Option D. Decreased hearing: Hearing loss is frequently observed in otitis media due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear, which impairs sound conduction temporarily.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Battle’s sign is not associated with otitis media but is indicative of basilar skull fractures involving the temporal bone. This distinction is important in clinical practice to differentiate between middle ear infections and traumatic injuries to the skull base. Recognizing Battle's sign should prompt further investigation for cranial fractures rather than ear infections.

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of immunization for her newborn. She is particularly interested in understanding the BCG vaccine's benefits, as she has heard conflicting opinions from friends and family. Based on current evidence and guidelines, which of the following best describes the primary protective effects of the BCG vaccine in the context of tuberculosis (TB)? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) CNS and disseminated TB 

 

  • BCG vaccine provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB.

 

BCG Vaccine

 

  • LIVE, Attenuated, Lyophilised vaccine
  • Reconstituent – NORMAL SALINE
  • Strain DANISH–1331 (VIA M. BOVIS, 239 SC FOR 13 YR)
  • Dose 0.05 (upto 28 days, then 0.1 ml) ID, just above insertion of left deltoid
  • Efficacy 0-80% (MEDIAN-50%)
  • Dose at birth, 1 TU in 0.1 ml
  • 20 years protection {No protection against pulmonary TB}

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

The condition depicted in the image is perichondrial hematoma, commonly resulting from blunt trauma to the ear. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires medical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the permanent deformity known as cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: This is true. If untreated, the hematoma can lead to fibrosis and calcification, causing a deformity known as cauliflower ear or pugilistic ear.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: True. The swelling and discoloration are due to blood accumulating in the perichondrial space, which separates the ear cartilage from the overlying skin.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is considered a good practice to prevent infection, especially since the ear's vascular supply is compromised, increasing the risk of perichondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondrial hematoma does not resolve on its own and requires prompt medical treatment to prevent complications like infection and the formation of cauliflower ear. Management typically involves aspiration of the hematoma, application of a pressure dressing to maintain ear contour, and administration of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IB

 

According to Radkowski, the staging system mass in the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, indicates Stage IB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IA: This stage involves tumors limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx, without any extension into the sinuses.

 

Option C. Stage IIA: Describes minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa, which is not indicated in this patient.

 

Option D. Stage IIB: Indicates occupation of the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital apex, which also does not apply to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THE RADKOWSKI STAGING SYSTEM FOR JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The identified anatomical feature corresponds to the sphenoid sinus, which effectively empties into the Sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: This meatus drains the posterior ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for several other sinuses, including the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. It is the most common drainage site for these sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, which is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. It does not play a role in draining any of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

choices.text: Eustachian tube dysfunction

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the ENT clinic with progressive hearing loss in her left ear that began shortly after her first pregnancy. She describes her hearing as better in noisy environments and denies any history of ear pain, discharge, or previous infections. Physical examination is unremarkable, but audiometry shows characteristic finding (image). Based on the clinical presentation and audiogram findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Otosclerosis

 

Explanation:


Otosclerosis is a condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling in the middle ear, particularly affecting the stapes. It commonly presents in young adults, especially women, and can be triggered or worsened by hormonal changes such as pregnancy. The hallmark of otosclerosis on audiometry is conductive hearing loss with a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve, known as Carhart’s notch, along with an air-bone gap. The disease is most often localized to the stapes footplate (stapedial type) and can be associated with a positive family history, tinnitus, and occasionally vertigo. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by audiometric findings.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Eustachian tube dysfunction: This condition is associated with pressure imbalances in the middle ear, often resulting in conductive hearing loss and retracted tympanic membrane. However, it does not cause Carhart’s notch or the specific audiometric pattern seen in otosclerosis.

 

Option C. Tympanosclerosis: Tympanosclerosis is characterized by calcification and scarring of the tympanic membrane and middle ear structures, often following chronic ear infections. It leads to conductive hearing loss but lacks the distinctive Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz on the audiogram.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Cholesteatoma is an abnormal skin growth in the middle ear behind the eardrum that often presents with chronic ear discharge, conductive hearing loss, and retraction pockets. It does not present with the audiometric finding of Carhart’s notch, distinguishing it from otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below cause?(AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

 

This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.

 

Option C. Tinnitus: Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

 

Common repair mechanism in mammalian cells.

 

  • Error-prone: It can introduce insertions or deletions (indels) at the cut site.
  • This mechanism is frequently used in CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt gene function (gene knock-out).

 

Many clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9)-based genome editing technologies take advantage of Cas nucleases to induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) at desired locations within a genome. Further processing of the DSBs by the cellular DSB repair machinery is then necessary to introduce desired mutations, sequence insertions, or gene deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision: This repair mechanism corrects single-base lesions that do not significantly distort the DNA helix, typically involving the removal of damaged bases by glycosylases followed by endonuclease action.

 

Option C. Homologous End Joining: This term is not commonly used in the context of DSB repair. The correct term would be Homologous Recombination (HR), which is an accurate repair mechanism but not the predominant one in CRISPR-Cas9-mediated repairs.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair: This mechanism corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops formed during DNA replication and recombination, but it is not primarily involved in repairing DSBs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

The given clinical scene and image shows a post-op tracheal stump created for breathing in patients of total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

 

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

 

Complications after total laryngectomy:

 

  • Permanent tracheostomy: upper end of trachea is directly sutured to skin for the patient to breathe.
  • Speech difficulties: To help patient speak after removal of larynx, there are various techniques.

 

1. Oesophageal speech:  patient is taught to swallow air and release which vibrates pharyngo-oesophageal segment and produces a very low sound.

 

2. Tracheo-oesophageal speech: most effective, artificial prostheses like Blom-singer valve / Provox / Groningen are inserted.

 

3. Electrolarynx: electrical device held on the skin of the neck vibrates and produce voice.

 

  • Loss of smell and decreased taste sensation
  • Swallowing difficulty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.

 

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Involves creating a larger incision in the neck to access the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below:  (INICET Nov 2021)

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

Based on the provided tympanogram findings, it is likely that the tuning fork tests for this patient would reveal a positive left Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the right ear (normal ear).

 

 

INTERPRETATION OF AUDIOGRAM

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.
  • In the question given above, left sided air conduction and bone conduction curves do not have any gap and they are occupying middle part of the graph. Hence, it is left SNHL.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear: This result would be expected in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL.

 

Option B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This also indicates conductive hearing loss, which is not supported by the audiogram findings.

 

Option D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This would indicate normal hearing or mild hearing loss in the right ear, which does not match the audiogram showing significant SNHL in the left ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: The scraping of a painless genital ulcer, when stained with Gram stain and viewed under the microscope, shows a gram-negative coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella granulomatis

 

The above description of a gram stain showing Gram-negative Coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils is suggestive of Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium donovani)

 

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

 

 

Microscopically, the margin of the ulcer shows epithelial hyperplasia. The ulcer bed shows neutrophilic abscesses. The dermis and subcutaneous tissues are infiltrated by numerous histiocytes containing many bacteria called Donovan bodies, and lymphocytes, plasma cells and neutrophils. These organisms are best demonstrated by silver impregnation techniques.

 

Klebsiella granulomatis is difficult to culture and diagnosis needs visualization of dark-staining Donovan bodies on tissue crush preparation or biopsy. The organisms are demonstrable in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate as a minute, encapsulated Coccobacilli (Donovan bodies) in macrophages.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis and Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Both are gram-negative diplococci, not coccobacilli, making them inconsistent with the gram-negative coccobacillus described in the question.

 

Option B. Hemophilus ducreyi: This bacterium, which causes chancroid, typically presents with a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain and is associated with painful genital ulcers, not the painless ulcer described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 664

choices.text: Superior olivary nucleus
Medial geniculate body

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty hearing, particularly in noisy environments, and trouble localizing sounds. His symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past year. He has no history of ear infections, trauma, or exposure to loud noise. A complete hearing evaluation shows no peripheral hearing loss, and the physician suspects a central auditory pathway issue. Which of the following structures is primarily responsible for sound localization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Superior olivary nucleus

 

Explanation:


The Superior olivary nucleus is the third structure in the auditory pathway sequence and plays a critical role in sound localization. It receives input from the cochlear nucleus and helps determine the direction of sound by comparing the timing and intensity of sound signals received by both ears. This function is essential for understanding the spatial origin of sounds. The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve, Cochlear Nucleus, Superior Olivary nucleus, Lateral lemniscus, Inferior colliculus, Medial geniculate body, and Auditory cortex (E COLI MA).

 

Other Options:


Option A. Inferior colliculus: The Inferior colliculus is involved in auditory processing and integration of sound signals but comes later in the sequence, after the lateral lemniscus, making it the fifth structure in the auditory pathway.

 

Option C. Medial geniculate body: This structure is part of the thalamic relay system that processes and directs auditory information to the auditory cortex, occurring later in the auditory pathway sequence, specifically as the sixth structure.

 

Option D. Cochlear nucleus: The Cochlear nucleus is the second structure in the auditory pathway, receiving input directly from the eighth nerve. It processes sound information and relays it to the superior olivary nucleus, but it is not primarily responsible for sound localization.

 

Educational Objective:


The Superior olivary nucleus is the third structure in the auditory pathway and is crucial for sound localization. The correct sequence of the auditory pathway, starting from the periphery and ending at the auditory cortex, follows the order Eighth nerve, Cochlear Nucleus, Superior Olivary nucleus, Lateral lemniscus, Inferior colliculus, Medial geniculate body, and Auditory cortex (E COLI MA). Understanding this sequence is important for diagnosing disorders affecting different levels of the auditory system.

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis inhibition
Cell membrane inhibition
Peptide synthesis inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cell wall synthesis inhibition

 

Vancomycin binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive agent like MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like polymyxins target the cell membrane.

 

Option C. Peptide synthesis inhibition: This option is incorrect. Peptide synthesis inhibition is typically the mechanism of action for drugs like tetracyclines and macrolides that interfere with ribosomal function.

 

Option D. 50S ribosome inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), chloramphenicol, and clindamycin inhibit the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing peptidoglycan elongation and cross-linking, leading to cell lysis and death. It is especially effective against gram-positive bacteria like MRSA.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to you with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal os

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of placenta previa which is caused due to placental implantation at the internal os.
  • Although the term placenta previa is diagnosed after 28 weeks, it can present with profuse bleeding at earlier gestational ages also.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: This will not present as profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks. This will present at a much earlier gestational age (6-8 weeks) and presents with abdominal pain (ruptured ectopic), vaginal bleeding (not profuse) and amenorrhoea (6-8 weeks)

 

Option C. Ovarian: Presents like an ectopic in the fallopian tube

 

Option D. Abdominal: This has varied presentations, but doesn’t present with profuse vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental implantation at the internal os, causing placenta previa, can lead to profuse vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 657, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Preservative commonly used for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formalin

 

  • Chemical for preservation for histopathology samples: Formalin. But it is not used as preservative for Toxicological analysis because extraction of poison becomes difficult.
  • Chemicals used for Preservation of Viscera for Toxicological analysis: Anyone of the following two preservatives may be used:

 

1) Saturated solution of common salt (NaCl, i.e. sodium chloride):

 

  1. Most commonly used preservative (easily available & cheap)
  2. It is indicated in all poisoning cases except Corrosives

 

2) Rectified spirit:

 

  1. Best preservative
  2. Indicated for most of the poisons except alcohol, acetic acid, Chloral hydrate, Chloroform, formaldehyde, formic acid, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, Phenol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl Alcohol: Not commonly used for histopathological tissue preservation due to its dehydration properties, which can alter tissue morphology.

 

Option C. Saturated Salt Solution: Commonly used as a preservative for toxicological analysis. It is easy to obtain and cost-effective. However, it is not suitable for preserving tissue for histopathology because it does not adequately preserve tissue morphology and detail.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Primarily used for medical procedures and as a temporary transport medium. It does not provide the long-term preservation needed for histopathological examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formalin is the preservative of choice for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination due to its ability to maintain tissue morphology and cellular details.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a positive Trendelenburg test. Identify the nerve injured: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior gluteal nerve

 

  • Function: It innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae. These muscles are significant abductors of the hip and play a critical role in pelvis stabilization during walking.
  • Clinical Significance: If this nerve were injured and the patient stood on the left leg, the right side of the pelvis would drop due to the inability to stabilize the pelvis on the stance leg. However, if the Trendelenburg test was positive on the right side, it wouldn't correlate with the left superior gluteal nerve injury.
  • A positive Trendelenburg test indicates a superior gluteal nerve injury.

 

The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus and is composed of fibers from L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves. It innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. The nerve exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and then courses over the surface of the gluteus medius muscle. A lesion to the superior gluteal nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, leading to a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior Gluteal Nerve:

 

  • Function: This nerve primarily innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. The gluteus maximus is the primary extensor of the hip and plays a role in the lateral stabilization of the hip.
  • Clinical Significance: Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve would weaken hip extension but would not directly result in a positive Trendelenburg test.

 

Option C. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Function: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the lower spine. It primarily innervates the muscles of the thigh, leg, and foot. It has two major branches, the tibial nerve and the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which provide motor and sensory function to the lower limb.
  • Clinical Significance: Sciatic nerve compression or irritation can result in a condition known as sciatica. Sciatica is characterized by pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness in the lower back, buttock, and down the back of the leg. Common causes include herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or muscle spasms.

 

Option D. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Function: The femoral nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus and provides motor and sensory innervation to the muscles of the thigh and hip joint. It plays a crucial role in thigh flexion and sensation in the anterior thigh and part of the leg.
  • Clinical Significance: Damage or compression of the femoral nerve can lead to symptoms like weakness in thigh muscles, difficulty walking, and sensory deficits in the anterior thigh. Rehabilitation and physical therapy are often used to address femoral nerve issues.

 

Both nerves are vital for the proper function of the lower limbs, and any disturbances or injuries to these nerves can have significant clinical implications, often requiring medical intervention and rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior gluteal nerve's role in stabilizing the pelvis during gait is critical. A positive Trendelenburg test indicates an inability to maintain pelvic stability due to weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, typically stemming from an injury to the superior gluteal nerve. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and managing conditions related to hip stability and gait abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

choices.text: 5 alpha reductase deficiency
17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
Androgen insensitivity syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas-based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."

 

The sterilization chamber is evacuated and hydrogen peroxide solution is injected from a cassette and is vaporized in the sterilization chamber to a concentration of 6 mg/l. The hydrogen peroxide vapor diffuses through the chamber (50 minutes), exposes all surfaces of the load to the sterilant, and initiates the inactivation of microorganisms. An electrical field created by a radio frequency is applied to the chamber to create a gas plasma. Microbicidal free radicals (e.g., hydroxyl and hydroperoxyl) are generated in the plasma. The excess gas is removed and in the final stage (i.e., vent) of the process the sterilization chamber is returned to atmospheric pressure by introduction of high-efficiency filtered air. The by-products of the cycle (e.g., water vapor, oxygen) are nontoxic and eliminate the need for aeration.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethylene oxide: Ethylene oxide is a gas used for sterilization, particularly for items that cannot withstand high temperatures. It is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are used for radiation sterilization, a different method that utilizes high-energy photons to sterilize equipment. They are not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option D. UV rays: UV rays are used for surface sterilization and disinfection. They are not part of the plasma sterilization process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma sterilization makes use of hydrogen peroxide vapor, which is activated into a plasma state by an electrical field, generating microbicidal free radicals that effectively inactivate microorganisms. This method is efficient and leaves nontoxic by-products, making it suitable for sterilizing sensitive medical and laboratory equipment.

questions.text: Which of these classifications of bile duct injury takes into account the location of injury, and thermal and vascular injury to bile ducts? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hannover 

 

  • When discussing bile duct injuries, several classification systems have been developed to categorize these injuries based on their nature, location, and the extent of damage. 

 

This system categorizes bile duct injuries based on the anatomical structure involved and the extent of the injury, including vascular injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bismuth Classification: Primarily focuses on the location of the bile duct injury in relation to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. This classification is widely used to describe bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy.

 

Option B. Strassberg Classification (also known as the Strassberg-Bismuth classification): This is an extension of the Bismuth classification, adding more detail and incorporating the critical view of safety concept. It includes acute injuries, but it is based on location alone. Associated vascular injuries are not included.

 

Option C. Stewart-Way Classification: This classification focuses on the phase of the operation in which the injury occurs and the type of injury, including thermal damage. It categorizes injuries into four types:

 

  1. Type I: Cystic duct leak or leakage from a small peripheral hepatic radicle close to the gallbladder fossa.
  2. Type II: Injury to the main bile duct that does not involve excision, typically a lateral injury.
  3. Type III: Complete transaction or excision of a segment of the main bile duct.
  4. Type IV: Injury involving damage to the hepatic duct confluence and bifurcation.

 

Stewart-Way classification does not account for associated vascular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bismuth and Strassberg classifications are anatomically based classifications of bile duct injury.

questions.text: False about the Ebola virus is: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmitted by mosquito

 

Ebola viruses belong to a family of viruses termed Filoviridae. Filovirus particles form long, sometimes branched, filaments of varying shapes, as well as shorter filaments. Viral particles contain one molecule of single-stranded negative-sense RNA, enveloped in a lipid (fatty) membrane.

 

Mode of transmission - direct contact with blood or other bodily fluids, such as semen, feces, or vomit, of infected persons (or animals), including close contact with deceased EVD victims, which are highly infectious.

 

Reservoir hosts – Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir

 

Accidental Hosts – Man

 

Incubation period - 2 to 21 days.

 

Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Nosocomial transmission seen.

 

Symptoms – severe headache muscle and joint pain, weakness and fatigue, sore throat, loss of appetite, gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting, Unexplained hemorrhaging, bleeding or bruising.

 

Treatment – symptomatic and supportive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a filovirus: This is true. Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and forms filamentous viral particles containing single-stranded negative-sense RNA.

 

Option C. Bats act as reservoir: This is true. Fruit bats are considered the most likely natural reservoir hosts for the Ebola virus.

 

Option D. Nosocomial transmission seen: This is true. Nosocomial transmission, which occurs in healthcare settings, is a recognized mode of transmission for Ebola virus, often due to inadequate infection control practices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is a filovirus transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals, not by mosquitoes. Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir, and nosocomial transmission is a known route of spread.

choices.text: Carcinoma of the larynx
Bilateral vocal cord paralysis

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking and chronic hoarseness presents to the ENT clinic with worsening breathing difficulties and dysphagia over the past few months. He has lost significant weight and has been experiencing progressive stridor, especially at night. On physical examination, there is a palpable mass in the neck, and laryngoscopy reveals a suspicious lesion obstructing the airway at the level of the glottis. Due to increasing airway obstruction, the patient is scheduled for a tracheostomy to secure the airway before undergoing further surgical intervention. The surgeon discusses the type of tracheostomy planned given the nature of the disease. Which of the following is an indication for performing a high tracheostomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Carcinoma of the larynx

 

Explanation:


A high tracheostomy is performed above the thyroid isthmus, usually violating the first tracheal ring, which can lead to complications such as perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis. However, the only clear indication for a high tracheostomy is in the case of laryngeal carcinoma, where the total larynx will ultimately be removed during surgery. In these cases, concerns about subglottic damage are less relevant because a fresh tracheostome will be created at a clean, lower level after laryngectomy, thus avoiding complications associated with high placement.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Tracheal stenosis: Tracheal stenosis is managed with a tracheostomy placed below the level of the stenosis to ensure a patent airway, not a high tracheostomy, which could worsen airway compromise.

 

Option C. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis: This condition can necessitate a tracheostomy for airway management, but it does not require high placement, which risks damage to the subglottic area and cricoid cartilage.

 

Option D. Obstructive sleep apnea: Tracheostomy is rarely indicated for obstructive sleep apnea and, when necessary, is performed at a standard level below the thyroid isthmus to prevent complications related to high placement.

 

Educational Objective:


High tracheostomy is specifically indicated in cases of laryngeal carcinoma due to the need for eventual laryngectomy, allowing for a fresh tracheostome to be created in a new, clean area. This avoids the complications associated with high tracheostomy in other conditions, where a standard placement is more appropriate.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

 

In this baby:

 

  • Color, blue - score 0
  • Heart rate, <100 beats/min - score 1
  • Grimace- score 1
  • Some flexion of the extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

 

Thus the total score is 4.

 

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

 

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An Apgar score is calculated based on five criteria, each ranging from 0 to 2. A score of 0-3 indicates severe distress, 4-6 indicates moderate difficulty, and 7-10 indicates that the newborn is in good health. The described baby, with a total score of 4, requires close monitoring and possibly further medical intervention.

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cell

 

The marked cell is Mast cell which is stained deep blue with Toluidine blue.

 

 

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and these cells are responsible for the allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

 

When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulation occurs releasing various mediators like Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin, Lipid mediators (Leukotriene C4, D4), prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor cytokines (TNF, IL 1).

choices.text: Teratozoospermia
Asthenozoospermia
Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

questions.text: The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis? 5 million/mI concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligospermia

 

Explanation:

 

The given semen analysis results show a sperm concentration of 5 million/mL, which is below the normal reference value set by the WHO. According to the WHO 2021 guidelines, a normal sperm concentration is 16 million/mL or higher. Therefore, this patient has oligospermia, which is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL. Counts below 5 million/mL are considered severe.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Oligospermia: Sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is when counts are <5 million/mL.
  • Teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenozoospermia: No motile sperms or diminished motility.
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: A combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology. The morphology here is 4%, which is within the normal range according to WHO criteria.

 

Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility. In this case, the motility is 50%, which is normal.

 

Option D. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: This term describes a condition where there is a combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. In this case, only the sperm concentration is abnormal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL, with counts below 5 million/mL considered severe. The given semen analysis results show oligospermia based on the sperm concentration of 5 million/mL.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 442, Duttas textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine

questions.text: A patient presented with periorbital pain and nasal discharge. On examination, the findings shown in the image below. She is an immunocompromised patient currently on HAART. Which of the following antifungal regimen should be prescribed to this patient along with HAART? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole

 

An immunocompromised patient presenting with peri-orbital swelling and black necrosed lesion is suggestive of mucormycosis, an opportunistic fungal infection.

 

  • Amphotericin B is the first-line treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad-spectrum antifungal activity. Posaconazole is used for consolidation therapy following initial treatment with Amphotericin B, especially in cases of severe infection or in immunocompromised patients.
  • Treatment of the underlying immunodeficiency along with surgical debridement might be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole: This regimen is not the most recommended for mucormycosis. Itraconazole is less effective compared to posaconazole for mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole: Fluconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. It is primarily used for infections caused by Candida and Cryptococcus species.

 

Option D. Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine: Flucytosine is used in combination with Amphotericin B for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, not mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis requires aggressive treatment with Amphotericin B followed by consolidation therapy with posaconazole, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This combination helps ensure both initial and sustained control of the fungal infection.

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the Graph is suggestive of:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Michaelis Menten kinetics

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaels - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.

 

Here, Vmax represents the maximum rate achieved by the system, happening at saturating substrate concentration for a given enzyme concentration. When the value of the Michaelis constant Km is numerically equal to the substrate concentration, then the reaction rate is half of Vmax. Biochemical reactions involving a single substrate are often assumed to follow Michaelis–Menten kinetics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allosteric Activation: This typically results in a sigmoid (S-shaped) curve rather than a hyperbolic one, as allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding.

 

Option B. Cooperative Binding: This is also characterized by a sigmoid curve, indicating that the binding of substrate to one active site affects the binding at other active sites.

 

Option D. Sigmoid Curve: This type of curve is associated with allosteric enzymes and cooperative binding, not with Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Michaelis-Menten kinetics is characterized by a hyperbolic curve where Vmax is the maximum rate achieved, and Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax.

questions.text: The given instrument is used in: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown is a Doyen's retractor, which is specifically used in cesarean sections. It plays a crucial role during the surgical procedure by retracting the bladder to provide proper exposure of the lower uterine segment. This retraction helps in ensuring a clear view and access to the uterus while minimizing the risk of bladder injury. The Doyen's retractor is used once the utero-vesical fold of peritoneum is opened and the bladder is dissected away from the lower uterine segment. It holds the bladder away from the site of the uterine incision, facilitating a safer and more efficient cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Involves the removal of the uterus through the vaginal canal and typically uses different types of retractors and instruments designed for vaginal access, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Option C. Manchester operation: This is a surgical procedure used to correct uterovaginal prolapse and does not involve the use of Doyen's retractor.

 

Option D. Fothergill's surgery: This is performed for uterovaginal prolapse and uses different instruments tailored for vaginal repairs, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doyen's retractor is used during cesarean sections to retract the bladder and prevent bladder injury while providing exposure of the lower uterine segment.
