Ref: Page no 751, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Nicotine gum

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation. Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptors. It is one of the 1st line oral drugs that is used for smoking cessation. The other drugs are Bupropion, even Nicotine replacement in the form of gums, lozenge, patch, spray can also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buspirone: Primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders, buspirone is not used for smoking cessation. Bupropion is used for smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Nicotine gum: As a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), nicotine gum helps to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by supplying a small amount of nicotine. While effective for many people, it may be less effective than prescription medications like varenicline, especially for heavy smokers.

 

Option D. Rimonabant: This drug was initially developed as an anti-obesity medication and was found to also have some effect on smoking cessation. However, it was withdrawn from the market due to psychiatric side effects, including depression and suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a medication that belongs to the class of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. Although it is primarily used to manage diabetes by promoting glucose excretion through urine, it has been found to have significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Mechanism of Action in Heart Failure: Empagliflozin improves cardiac outcomes through several mechanisms:

 

  • Reduction in preload and afterload: By promoting diuresis and natriuresis, empagliflozin reduces the volume overload, which is beneficial in heart failure.
  • Improvement in myocardial metabolism: It shifts myocardial substrate utilization from glucose to ketone bodies, which is more energy-efficient for the failing heart.
  • Reduction in cardiac fibrosis and inflammation: Empagliflozin has anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects, which help in reducing cardiac remodeling and progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrochlorothiazide: This is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to manage hypertension and mild fluid retention. However, it does not have significant benefits in delaying the progression of heart failure.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not specifically alter the progression of the disease.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure to improve symptoms and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, but it does not have a mortality benefit or significantly delay the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes mastoidectomy due to chronic otitis media with mastoid involvement. During the procedure, various structures of the middle and inner ear are identified to ensure proper surgical navigation and avoid complications. The surgeon points out a critical structure that plays a key role in balance and spatial orientation, which must be carefully preserved during surgery. Based on the provided image of a mastoidectomy, which structure corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. A

 

Explanation:


Label A in the image corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal, which is part of the vestibular system of the inner ear. The lateral semicircular canal is crucial for maintaining balance and detecting head movements in the horizontal plane. It can be identified by its distinct position relative to other structures like the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle. Preservation of the lateral semicircular canal is essential during mastoidectomy to prevent vertigo and balance disturbances postoperatively.

 

 

Other Options:


Option B. B corresponds to the posterior semicircular canal, which is involved in detecting head movements in the sagittal plane. While it is also part of the vestibular system, it is anatomically distinct from the lateral semicircular canal and has a different orientation.

 

Option C. C represents the sigmoid sinus, a large venous structure located posteriorly, unrelated to the vestibular system. Its identification is critical during surgery to avoid bleeding complications but is not involved in balance.

 

Option D. D corresponds to the tegmen, the thin bony plate separating the middle ear from the cranial cavity. It is not part of the vestibular system and does not play a role in maintaining balance.

 

Educational Objective:


The lateral semicircular canal is an essential component of the vestibular system, responsible for detecting rotational movements of the head. Its careful identification and preservation during mastoidectomy are critical to maintaining normal balance and preventing postoperative complications such as vertigo.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The centromeric pattern is characterized by distinct dots in the nucleus, corresponding to centromeres during cell division. This pattern is associated with anti-centromere antibodies (ACA), commonly seen in limited cutaneous scleroderma (CREST syndrome). ACA antibody is  correlate with pulmonary hypertension seen in patients with limited disease. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogenous: Diffuse staining of the nucleus, seen with anti-ds DNA antibodies or anti-histone antibodies.
 

Option C. Speckled: Numerous fine or coarse speckles, a kind of quite nonspecific, associated with various antibodies such as anti-SEL70, anti-JOAN, and anti-SMITH antibodies, etc
 

Option D. Nucleolar: Prominent nucleolar staining, quite nonspecific, seen with Anti-PM-Scl antibody, an overlap antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centromeric pattern in ANA staining is associated with anti-centromere antibodies and limited scleroderma.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter.

 

Acinetobacter species are particularly prevalent in hospital settings and are a common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). These organisms are known for their ability to survive on surfaces for extended periods and their resistance to multiple antibiotics, making them a significant concern in intensive care units where patients are often intubated. Acinetobacter, along with Pseudomonas and Stenotrophomonas, is known for colonizing the respiratory tract of ventilated patients, leading to VAP, which typically occurs after 48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: This genus, including species like Clostridium difficile, is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, rather than pneumonia.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, it is generally less common than Acinetobacter in this specific infection context. Klebsiella tends to be more associated with community-acquired pneumonia and hospital-acquired infections outside of the ventilator context.

 

Option D. Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections but is more commonly linked to community-acquired pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rather than VAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acinetobacter, pseudomonas, stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia cepacia are common organisms causing VAP. VAP occurs due to colonization by organisms in < 48 hours.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Pneumonia/Chap 142

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, i.e.: - a wave in JVP (right atrial filling) -› First heart sound (closure of AV valve) -› T wave in ECG (ventricular systole) -> Rapid filling of ventricles.

 

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave (Electrical activity first i.e. repolarization) followed by rapid filling of ventricles (Mechanical activity i.e. relaxation).

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rivaroxaban

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Bivalirudin: Bivalirudin is an injectable direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor. It is used primarily in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI) and for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option B. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of stroke in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and for the treatment and prevention of DVT and PE.

 

Option D. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) administered via injection. It acts primarily by inhibiting factor Xa and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events. Other agents like bivalirudin, dabigatran, and enoxaparin have different mechanisms of action and routes of administration.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Niemann pick disease
Fish eye disease

questions.text: Identify the given image: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gaucher’s disease

 

  • Gaucher's disease is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms include bone pain, anemia, enlarged organs (hepatosplenomegaly), a swollen and painful belly, easy bruising, and fatigue.
  • Gaucher's disease is most common in Jewish people of Eastern and Central European descent (Ashkenazi).
  • It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolman's disease:

  • Wolman's disease is a rare autosomal recessive lipid storage disease.
  • It is caused by mutations in the LIPA gene, which encodes lysosomal acid lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down lipids.
  • Individuals with Wolman's disease have a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol and triglycerides in various organs, including the liver, spleen, and intestines.
  • Symptoms often appear in infancy and may include enlarged liver and spleen, abdominal distension, diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

 

Option C. Niemann-Pick disease:

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a rare inherited disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids) within cells.
  • There are several subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease, including types A, B, and C, each caused by different genetic mutations.
  • Symptoms can vary depending on the subtype but may include hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), neurological problems, and respiratory difficulties.
  • Type C Niemann-Pick disease, in particular, can lead to cognitive and motor impairment.

 

Option D. Fish eye disease:

  • Fish eye disease is a rare genetic disorder and is a variant of familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) deficiency.
  • It is characterized by a deficiency of the LCAT enzyme, which plays a role in cholesterol metabolism.
  • Fish eye disease leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and can cause eye problems, including corneal opacities and vision impairment.
  • Unlike the more severe form of LCAT deficiency, known as LCAT deficiency, Fish eye disease typically has milder symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

The long arm of chromosome 17 encodes the retinoic acid alpha receptor gene (RARA). It is primarily expressed in hematopoietic cells and plays an important role in gene expression regulation. RARA is bound by the nuclear corepressor factor in the absence of retinoid acid, causing transcriptional repression. RARA is activated in the presence of retinoic acid, and promyelocytes undergo terminal differentiation.

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute leukemia distinguished by abnormal promyelocyte proliferation, life-threatening coagulopathy, and the chromosome translocation t (15;17) (q22;q11-12). This results in an abnormal fusion protein known as PML-RARA, which has a low affinity for retinoids. This inhibits transcription and thus prevents gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

 

 

Rx: The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL: Associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

  • Treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, not ATRA.

 

Option C. CMYC: Associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

  • Involves translocation t (8;14) affecting the c-Myc oncogene.

 

Option D. RUNX1-ETO: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t (8;21).

 

  • Treated with standard chemotherapy regimens, not specifically ATRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.
